newsitem.title: USA: SEPTA responds to Phila. spending concerns - paper.
newsitem.headline: SEPTA responds to Phila. spending concerns - paper.

text.p: The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transporatation Authority plans to increase funding for capital projects in Philadelphia, responding to complaints from Mayor Ed Rendell that the city was being short-changed, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported Wednesday.
SEPTA plans to vote on its proposed $437 million budget next week, and has agreed to redirect more of its resources for projects in the city instead of the outlying suburbs, the newspaper said.
Among the projects now expected to see more funding are three trolley lines in North Philadelphia, improvements to Suburban Station, and a study of how to improve links to Penn's Landing.
In the secondary market Wednesday, SEPTA FGIC 5-3/8s of 2022 were offered at a 5.49 percent yield. Kenny Evaluation Services priced the bonds at the close Tuesday at 5.51 percent.
